column8:
Based on the available medical literature, Schwann Cell Precursor-like melanoma and neurofibromin 2 (NF2)-mutated schwannoma share activation of the MEK/ERK (MAPK) pathway and PI3K/AKT pathway as commonly dysregulated signaling mechanisms.[1-3]

The MEK/ERK pathway is a central convergence point in both tumor types. In NF2-mutated schwannomas, merlin loss leads to activation of the Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK signaling cascade through multiple mechanisms, including dysregulated receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) such as ErbB2/3, PDGFR-β, and IGF-1R.[2][4-6] Similarly, Schwann cell precursor-like melanoma demonstrates MEK/ERK pathway activation, with both conditions showing responsiveness to MEK inhibition with selumetinib.[1]

The PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway represents another shared signaling axis. Merlin normally suppresses this pathway, and its loss in NF2-mutated schwannomas results in constitutive PI3K/AKT activation.[2][5][7-8] This pathway is also implicated in Schwann cell precursor-like states and contributes to proliferation and survival in both tumor contexts.[1-2]

Additional shared mechanisms include PAK (p21-activated kinase) signaling, which is activated downstream of Rac in merlin-deficient cells.[1][9-11] Functional genomic screening has identified that NF2 loss and PAK activation underlie resistance to MEK inhibition, and concurrent MEK and PAK inhibition shows efficacy in preclinical models.[1]

The convergence of these pathways on cellular dedifferentiation programs is particularly notable, as DNA methylation groups of Schwann cell tumors can be distinguished by differentiation states that correlate with treatment response.[1]

column10:
Both the Schwann cell precursor (SCP)-like melanoma subtype and NF2-mutant schwannomas share elevated activity of the nerve growth factor receptor NGFR (also known as p75^NTR/CD271) and a highly active ERBB3 (HER3) signaling pathway. In melanoma, therapy-resistant cells can de-differentiate into an SCP-like state characterized by high NGFR expression and engagement of a neuregulin-driven ERBB3 signaling axis【1】【2】. Likewise, vestibular schwannomas driven by NF2 loss (merlin inactivation) exhibit strong p75^NTR/NGFR expression and rely on aberrant ErbB3 (in concert with ErbB2) receptor signaling for growth and survival【3】【4】. These common signaling features – p75^NTR and neuregulin-activated ErbB3 pathways – underlie the phenotypic convergence between SCP-like melanoma cells and NF2-mutated Schwann-cell tumors

A subset of melanoma cells can adopt a Schwann cell precursor-like phenotype that is marked by NGFR upregulation and ERBB3 activation, conferring resistance to immune attack. For instance, melanoma cells pre-existing in an NGFR^high dedifferentiated state are known to evade cytotoxic T cells and resist immunotherapies【1】. This neural crest/SCP-like melanoma state not only expresses NGFR (p75^NTR) but also co-opts Schwann-cell developmental signals – notably the neuregulin-1 (NRG1)/ERBB3 pathway – to maintain a de-differentiated, proliferative program【2】. Neuregulin/ErbB3 signaling in melanocytic cells inhibits differentiation (e.g. suppressing MITF-driven melanocyte maturation) and promotes a more progenitor-like, therapy-resistant phenotype【2】.

NF2-deficient schwannomas show strikingly parallel signaling features. Loss of the NF2 tumor suppressor (merlin) in Schwann cells unleashes aberrant growth factor signaling. Merlin-deficient vestibular schwannomas strongly express p75^NTR (NGFR), a hallmark of immature Schwann cells, which actively supports tumor cell survival via NF-κB signaling【4】. Concurrently, NF2-mutant Schwann tumors exhibit hyperactivation of ErbB family receptors, especially the ErbB2/ErbB3 complex, often driven by autocrine or paracrine neuregulin signals【3】. Indeed, studies have documented elevated ErbB2/3 phosphorylation in NF2-null schwannomas and demonstrated that blocking ErbB2/ErbB3 (e.g. with lapatinib or other ErbB inhibitors) suppresses Schwannoma cell proliferation【3】. This indicates that, similar to SCP-like melanoma cells, NF2-mutant Schwannoma cells depend on an active HER3/ERBB3 signaling axis for growth.

In summary, the common signaling factors shared by the SCP-like melanoma subset and NF2-mutated schwannomas are the NGFR (p75^NTR) receptor and the ErbB3 receptor tyrosine kinase pathway (mediated by neuregulin/ErbB2/ErbB3 interactions). Both tumor types exploit these Schwann-cell precursor associated signals to drive tumor cell survival, dedifferentiation, and therapy resistance【1】【2】【3】【4】.

column12:
The commonly shared signaling pathways between the NGFR- and ERBB3-high, schwann cell precursor (SCP)-like melanoma and NF2-mutated schwannoma are the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase (PI3K)/AKT pathways. Dysregulation of the Hippo signaling pathway, specifically the overactivation of its effectors YAP/TAZ, is also a shared feature. 
Melanoma with high expression of nerve growth factor receptor (NGFR) and high ERBB3 activity exhibits a transcriptional state similar to schwann cell precursors (SCPs) and is resistant to immunotherapy and targeted MAPK inhibitors. This resistance is often linked to the activation of compensatory signaling pathways, notably the PI3K/AKT pathway. The high ERBB3 expression is connected to this drug-tolerant persister cell state, which has neural crest stem cell features. 
Schwannomas, particularly those in the context of Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), are characterized by the inactivation of the NF2 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes the protein merlin. Loss of functional merlin leads to the constitutive, uncontrolled activation of several mitogenic signaling pathways, which are critical for cell growth and proliferation. 
The shared signaling pathways identified in both conditions are:
MAPK/ERK pathway: In NF2-mutated schwannoma cells, loss of merlin leads to the overactivation of the MAPK/ERK (extracellular signal-regulated kinase) pathway. This pathway is also frequently dysregulated in melanoma and its continuous activity contributes to tumor growth.
PI3K/AKT pathway: The PI3K/AKT pathway is another mitogenic signaling cascade that is overactive in NF2-deficient schwannoma cells due to the loss of merlin's inhibitory function. In the SCP-like melanoma subtype, activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway is a key mechanism of resistance to MAPK pathway inhibitors, allowing the cells to maintain stem-like properties and survive.
Hippo pathway: Merlin is an upstream regulator of the Hippo tumor suppressor pathway. Its loss in schwannoma results in the inactivation of the Hippo pathway and the nuclear accumulation and overactivation of its effectors, YAP and TAZ, which promote cell proliferation and survival. The Hippo pathway has also been implicated in the molecular pathways sustaining slow-cycling cancer stem cells in melanoma, a phenotype associated with the SCP-like state and therapy resistance.

column3: What are the genetic and epigenetic features, and transcriptional programs specific to histological subtypes of melanoma? How are these features related to the origin of cells in each subtype?
column6:
ANSWER: Melanoma subtypes are distinguished by unique genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptional profiles that are closely linked to the developmental origin and anatomical location of the parent melanocyte.

- **Genetic Features:** Cutaneous melanoma (CM), originating from sun-exposed skin, has a high tumor mutational burden (TMB) and a strong ultraviolet radiation (UVR) signature, with common driver mutations in BRAF and NRAS. In contrast, acral (AM) and mucosal (MM) melanomas, arising from non-sun-exposed sites, have low TMB, no UVR signature, and are characterized by frequent structural variants and copy number alterations, including amplifications of genes like TERT, CCND1, and CDK4. Uveal melanoma (UM), originating from the eye, is genomically distinct, with the lowest TMB and driver mutations in G-protein signaling genes (GNAQ, GNA11) and genes like BAP1, SF3B1, and EIF1AX that define its molecular subtypes.

- **Epigenetic Features:** Epigenetic modifications, particularly DNA methylation, further define melanoma subtypes. In CM, a CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP) is associated with the lentigo maligna subtype and poor prognosis. AM subtypes, like primary acral lentiginous (PALM) and non-lentiginous (NALM), exhibit distinct methylation profiles, with prognostic implications for genes such as HHEX and NELFB. Mucosal melanomas also show site-specific epigenetic patterns; for instance, esophageal MM displays global hypermethylation and TERT promoter hypermethylation, which correlates with a better immunotherapy response compared to other mucosal sites. In UM, BAP1 loss is associated with a specific global DNA methylation state that distinguishes poor-prognosis from good-prognosis tumors.

- **Transcriptional Programs and Cell of Origin:** The transcriptional programs of melanoma subtypes are deeply rooted in their cell of origin. Acral melanoma retains the transcriptional signature of the volar-enriched melanocyte subpopulation from which it arises. Intra-tumor heterogeneity is a key feature, with cells existing in distinct states, such as a high-MITF (melanocytic) state or a high-AXL (mesenchymal-like) state, which influences therapy resistance. The anatomical origin dictates the primary molecular events; for example, KIT mutations are frequent in acral, mucosal, and chronically sun-damaged melanomas but rare elsewhere. The developmental role of key mutated genes, such as BAP1 in neural crest lineage commitment, further underscores the link between the tumor's biology and the developmental history of its originating cell.

ANALYSIS: 
### **An Overview of Melanoma and its Histological Subtypes**

Melanoma is a form of cancer that originates from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing melanin pigment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanoma). While it most commonly develops in the skin, it can also appear in other locations like the mouth, intestines, eyes, and, in extremely rare instances, the lungs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanoma). The progression of cutaneous melanoma is often characterized by discernible stages: an initial proliferation of transformed melanocytes above the epidermal basement membrane (in situ or epidermal radial growth phase), followed by invasion into the papillary dermis (micro-invasive radial growth phase), and finally, the acquisition of tumorigenic growth capacity (invasive vertical growth phase) (PMID: 28128089).

Primary cutaneous malignant melanomas are broadly classified into several clinico-pathological variants, including lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), and nodular melanoma (NM). An additional variant, acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM), is defined by its occurrence on acral regions such as the palms, soles, and under the nails (PMID: 6415910). Other major subtypes are defined by their location, such as uveal melanoma (UM) in the eyes and mucosal melanoma (MM) in internal mucous membranes (PMID: 36098958). Spitz tumours represent a distinct spectrum of melanocytic proliferations ranging from benign nevi to malignant melanomas, characterized by specific cytological features and molecular pathways (PMID: 34958498).

### **Genetic Features of Melanoma Subtypes**

The genetic landscape of melanoma is highly diverse, with distinct features characterizing its various subtypes. While most cutaneous, acral, and mucosal melanomas share alterations in core pathways like MAPK, PI3K, p53, p16, and telomere maintenance, the specific mechanisms activating or inactivating these pathways differ significantly among subtypes (PMID: 36098958).

#### **General Genetic Progression**
The development of melanoma often follows a sequential accumulation of genetic mutations. Studies show that precursor lesions are frequently initiated by mutations activating the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway. Unequivocally benign lesions typically harbor only BRAF V600E mutations. Intermediate lesions are enriched for NRAS mutations and other driver mutations. A significant proportion of intermediate lesions and melanomas in situ also acquire TERT promoter mutations, indicating this is an early event in neoplastic progression. Biallelic inactivation of CDKN2A is a feature of invasive melanomas, while PTEN and TP53 mutations are found predominantly in advanced primary melanomas. The burden of point mutations, strongly marked by a UV radiation signature, increases from benign lesions to melanoma (PMID: 26559571). Oncogenes like BRAFV600E require a specific cellular context, or "oncogenic competence," to initiate tumors, which can be influenced by signaling from cells in the microenvironment, such as keratinocytes (PMID: 37553760). Mouse models have shown that while expression of BRaf(V600E) alone leads to benign melanocytic hyperplasias, its combination with the silencing of the Pten tumor suppressor gene results in metastatic melanoma with 100% penetrance (PMID: 19282848).

#### **Cutaneous Melanoma (CM)**
Cutaneous melanoma is genomically classified into four subtypes based on prevalent mutated genes: mutant BRAF, mutant RAS, mutant NF1, and Triple-WT (wild-type for all three) (PMID: 26091043).
-   **BRAF and NRAS Mutations**: BRAF mutations are associated with characteristic morphological features and a higher frequency of metastasis to regional lymph nodes (PMID: 20874733). These mutations are most frequent in superficial spreading or nodular histological subtypes on intermittently sun-exposed skin and in younger patients (PMID: 16567964).
-   **PKC Fusion Genes**: A subset of cutaneous melanocytic neoplasms harbors fusion genes involving protein kinase C (PKC) homologs (PRKCA, PRKCB, PRKCG). These tumors often present in young adults and have distinct histological features resembling blue nevi. Similar to GNA-mutated blue nevi, these tumors can progress to melanoma, sometimes through the inactivation of BAP1 (PMID: 37474004).

#### **Acral and Mucosal Melanoma (AM and MM)**
Acral and mucosal melanomas are the predominant subtypes in Asian and other non-Caucasian populations and are not linked to UV radiation exposure (PMID: 37913653, PMID: 34149718).
-   **Mutational Burden and Genomic Structure**: Compared to cutaneous melanomas, acral melanomas have a significantly lower mutational burden but a higher number of copy number variants (PMID: 35974375). They share an aggressive phenotype and a similar genetic landscape, with many classified as triple wild-type (PMID: 34149718, PMID: 35974375).

#### **Uveal Melanoma (UM)**
Uveal melanoma is genomically distinct from other subtypes.
-   **Mutation Profile**: It has the lowest tumor mutation burden and lacks a UV radiation signature (PMID: 36098958, PMID: 27745836). Its genetic landscape is characterized by very few somatic mutations, making it more similar to pediatric tumors (PMID: 27745836). Key mutated genes are involved in the G-protein signaling pathway (PMID: 36098958).
-   **Molecular Subtypes**: Comprehensive analysis identifies four molecularly distinct subtypes: two associated with poor-prognosis monosomy 3 (M3) and two with better-prognosis disomy 3 (D3). Key driver mutations occur in GNAQ, GNA11, BAP1, EIF1AX, and SF3B1 (PMID: 28810145, PMID: 27745836).

#### **Spitz Tumors**
This group of melanocytic proliferations is characterized by distinct molecular pathways that separate them from conventional melanomas. The presence of specific aberrations, such as Harvey rat sarcoma viral oncogene homologue (HRAS) mutations or kinase fusions, defines a bona fide Spitz neoplasm, distinguishing it from Spitz-like melanomas that have conventional driver mutations (PMID: 34958498).

### **Epigenetic Features of Melanoma Subtypes**

Epigenetic alterations, particularly DNA methylation, play a crucial role in the heterogeneity and clinical behavior of melanoma subtypes.

#### **Cutaneous Melanoma (CM)**
-   **Multi-Omics Subtypes**: An integrative multi-omics analysis of cutaneous melanoma identified three robust molecular subtypes (CS1, CS2, CS3) with distinct genomic, epigenetic, and immune profiles. The CS2 subtype is immunologically "hot," with high tumor mutational burden and immune infiltration, and is associated with a favorable response to anti-PD-1 therapy. In contrast, CS1 and CS3 are "cold" subtypes with immune exclusion characteristics (PMID: 40574832). Another classification based on three omics datasets designated subtypes as "immune," "melanin," and "ion," which differed in clinical features and mutation frequencies of key genes (PMID: 29948145).
-   **CpG Island Methylator Phenotype (CIMP)**: Whole-genome methylation data from primary cutaneous melanomas identified a subclass with hypermethylation of CpG islands, known as CIMP. CIMP melanomas are associated with the lentigo maligna melanoma histological subtype, older age at diagnosis, higher tumor stage, and worse melanoma-specific survival. These tumors show hypermethylation of genes critical for melanoma progression and immunity, such as PTEN, VDR, and PD-L1 (PMID: 34843679).

#### **Acral Melanoma (AM)**
Genome-wide methylation analysis has revealed that primary acral lentiginous melanoma (PALM) and primary non-lentiginous AM (NALM) are epigenetically distinct. PALM is characterized by profound hypomethylation in the promoter regions of four specific genes compared to NALM. Notably, hypermethylation of two of these genes, HHEX and NELFB, is significantly correlated with poor overall and disease-specific survival (PMID: 31888295).

#### **Mucosal Melanoma (MM)**
Mucosal melanomas exhibit distinct epigenetic signatures based on their anatomical site of origin. A study comparing primary malignant melanoma of the esophagus (PMME) with non-esophageal mucosal melanoma (NEMM) found that PMME has a unique epigenetic profile characterized by global hypermethylation. Hypermethylation of the TERT promoter was observed in PMME and correlated with increased CD8+ T-cell infiltration and improved responses to immunotherapy, suggesting that the epigenetic status of TERT could be a prognostic and predictive biomarker (PMID: 38695555).

#### **Uveal Melanoma (UM)**
The molecular subtypes of uveal melanoma are defined by both genetic and epigenetic features. The loss of the BAP1 gene, which typically follows the loss of one copy of chromosome 3 (monosomy 3), is correlated with a distinct global DNA methylation state that separates poor-prognosis tumors from those with a better prognosis (PMID: 28810145).

### **Transcriptional Programs in Melanoma Subtypes**

Transcriptional regulation is essential for maintaining cell identity and plasticity in melanoma, with various signaling pathways and oncogenic drivers causing changes in mRNA transcription that drive tumor initiation and progression (PMID: 33024276).

#### **Transcriptional Heterogeneity and Therapy Resistance**
-   **Cell States**: Malignant cells within a single tumor exhibit transcriptional heterogeneity. For example, tumors often contain a mix of cells in two distinct states: one with high levels of the MITF transcription factor and another with low MITF and elevated levels of the AXL kinase, a program associated with drug resistance (PMID: 27124452).
-   **Resistance Signatures**: A mesenchymal-like (MES) transcriptional state, regulated by the master transcription factor TCF4, is known to confer resistance to targeted therapy and is enriched in non-responders to immune checkpoint blockade (PMID: 38181739). An innate anti-PD-1 resistance signature (IPRES) has also been identified, characterized by the upregulation of genes involved in mesenchymal transition, cell adhesion, and angiogenesis (PMID: 26997480).

#### **Subtype-Specific and Prognostic Transcriptional Programs**
-   **Cell of Origin Signatures**: Transcriptional programs can be traced back to the cell of origin. A distinct transcriptional signature found in a subpopulation of melanocytes enriched in volar skin (palms and soles) is retained in acral melanomas (PMID: 34475532).
-   **Tumor Microenvironment Interactions**: Transcriptional programs also reflect interactions within the tumor microenvironment (TME). Single-cell RNA sequencing has defined numerous cell types, subtypes, and transcriptional hallmarks of malignant cells within metastatic melanoma (PMID: 40890106). In a comparison of mucosal and acral melanomas, MM was dominated by subpopulations with high epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition potential, while AM was enriched with cancer-associated fibroblasts that promote tumor proliferation (PMID: 40192737).
-   **Prognostic Models**: Transcriptional signatures can have prognostic value. An "adenosine signaling score" (ADO-score) model was developed to quantify adenosine signaling status. A high ADO-score correlates with metabolic and proliferation hallmarks and a "cold" TME, leading to worse clinical outcomes, while a low score is linked to antitumor immunity signatures and a "hot" TME (PMID: 39278925). Similarly, metastatic melanomas can be clustered into "immune-high" and "immune-low" subtypes, with the former showing higher immune cell infiltration and better clinical outcomes (PMID: 41234896).
-   **Uveal Melanoma**: The four molecularly distinct subtypes of UM (two M3 and two D3) have divergent transcriptional features that correlate with genomic aberrations and clinical outcomes (PMID: 28810145).

### **Relationship Between Molecular Features and Cell of Origin**

The distinct genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptional landscapes of melanoma subtypes are deeply intertwined with the anatomical location and developmental history of the melanocytes from which they arise.

-   **Cutaneous Melanoma**: Arising from sun-exposed skin, the high TMB and strong UV signature are direct consequences of environmental exposure acting on epidermal melanocytes (PMID: 26559571, PMID: 32057276). Histological subtypes like superficial spreading melanoma (low cumulative solar damage) and lentigo maligna melanoma (high cumulative solar damage) reflect this etiological link (PMID: 32057276). The local microenvironment is also crucial; for instance, GABAergic signaling between keratinocytes and melanocytes can promote the initiation of BRAFV600E-driven melanoma (PMID: 37553760).

-   **Acral Melanoma**: Originating from melanocytes on palms, soles, and nail beds, AM's unique molecular profile reflects a non-UVR etiology (PMID: 37913653). A critical link to its origin is the finding that the transcriptional signature of a volar-enriched melanocyte subpopulation, established during embryonic development, is retained in acral melanomas (PMID: 34475532). This indicates that innate developmental programs of the original cell population prefigure the tumor's transcriptional identity. The distinct epigenetic profiles of PALM versus NALM suggest that even within acral sites, different origins or early developmental pressures can lead to distinct tumor subtypes (PMID: 31888295).

-   **Mucosal Melanoma**: Originating from melanocytes in mucous membranes, MM's molecular features vary depending on the specific anatomical site. For example, the distinct global hypermethylation pattern of esophageal MM compared to other mucosal sites points to the local microenvironment of the originating cell shaping its epigenetic landscape and subsequent clinical behavior, such as response to immunotherapy (PMID: 38695555).

-   **Uveal Melanoma**: UM arises from melanocytes within the eye's uveal tract, a UV-protected environment. This origin is reflected in its unique genomic profile, which lacks a UV signature and is dominated by mutations in G-protein signaling pathways (GNAQ/GNA11) (PMID: 36098958, PMID: 27745836). The cell of origin's lineage is also significant; UM's capacity for phenotypic plasticity may be a consequence of its neural crest origin (PMID: 29049740). Furthermore, BAP1, a key tumor suppressor in UM, plays a critical role in embryonic development, specifically in the commitment to ectoderm, mesoderm, and neural crest lineages, directly linking a major cancer gene to the developmental biology of the melanocyte precursor cell (PMID: 31555735).

-   **Anatomical Site as a General Determinant**: The anatomical location of the primary melanoma is a strong determinant of its molecular subtype. For example, melanomas from acral, mucosal, and chronically sun-damaged sites frequently harbor activating mutations in the KIT gene, which are very rare in other cutaneous tumors (PMID: 20457136). This highlights how the specific niche of the originating melanocyte influences the selection of driver mutations. Different environmental and genetic factors related to geographic origin also significantly influence the presentation of the disease, affecting both the histological subtype and the prevalence of mutations in genes like BRAF, NRAS, and C-KIT (PMID: 32775409).

### **Conclusion and Insights**

The histological subtypes of melanoma are not merely descriptive categories but represent distinct biological entities whose genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptional characteristics are fundamentally shaped by the cell of origin and its anatomical microenvironment. The UV-driven, high-TMB profile of cutaneous melanoma contrasts sharply with the structural variant-driven, low-TMB profiles of acral and mucosal melanomas, and the unique G-protein pathway-mutated landscape of uveal melanoma.

A key insight from the evidence is that the identity of a melanoma subtype is predetermined to a large extent by the innate developmental programming and environmental niche of its parent melanocyte. The retention of a fetal-era transcriptional signature in acral melanoma is a powerful example of this principle. This suggests that tumorigenesis co-opts existing, location-specific biological programs rather than creating entirely new ones. Furthermore, epigenetic modifications serve as a critical layer of regulation that cements these subtype identities and dictates clinical behavior, as seen with the prognostic power of methylation patterns in acral, mucosal, and uveal melanomas. The concept of "oncogenic competence"—where the cellular context dictates the transforming ability of an oncogene—is central to understanding this diversity. Ultimately, a comprehensive molecular classification that integrates genomic, epigenomic, and transcriptomic data, viewed through the lens of the cell of origin's developmental biology, provides the most robust framework for understanding melanoma heterogeneity and developing subtype-specific therapeutic strategies.

column8:
Melanoma subtypes exhibit distinct genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptional features that correlate with their anatomical location and cellular origin. The major histological subtypes include superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM), mucosal melanoma, and desmoplastic melanoma, each characterized by unique mutational landscapes, UV exposure patterns, and developmental trajectories that reflect their melanocyte precursor populations. [1-2]

Genetic Features by Subtype
Superficial spreading melanoma, arising from melanocytes in intermittently sun-exposed skin, is characterized by BRAF V600E mutations in approximately 50-60% of cases.
[1][3] These tumors typically develop in younger adults on the trunk or back, often in association with precursor nevi, and exhibit moderate tumor mutational burden (TMB) related to UV exposure. [1-2]
Lentigo maligna melanoma, occurring in chronically sun-damaged skin of the head and neck in older patients, demonstrates frequent NF1 loss-of-function or NRAS mutations rather than BRAF mutations.[1] These tumors show severe solar elastosis and higher mutational loads due to cumulative UV damage. [1-2]
Acral and mucosal melanomas, arising in non-sun-exposed sites, are dominated by structural chromosomal changes rather than point mutations. [2] Acral melanomas frequently harbor CCND1 amplifications, while mucosal melanomas show recurrent SF3B1 mutations. [2][4] Both subtypes exhibit lower TMB and distinct mutation signatures unrelated to UV radiation. [2]
Desmoplastic melanoma, typically occurring in severely sun-damaged skin, demonstrates NF1 mutations and the highest TMB among melanoma subtypes, correlating with better immunotherapy responses and lower sentinel lymph node involvement. [1][4]
Epigenetic and Transcriptional Programs
Melanomas exhibit two major transcriptional types that cut across histological subtypes: a pigmentation/MITF-high program (associated with NRAS mutations) and an inflammatory/AXL-high program (associated with BRAF mutations or wild-type status). [5] These transcriptional states reflect different developmental trajectories and therapeutic vulnerabilities. [5]
Epigenetic alterations include TERT promoter mutations (the most frequent non-coding mutation, found in 30-80% of melanomas), abnormal DNA methylation patterns, histone modifications, and dysregulated microRNA expression. [3][6] CDKN2A loss, PTEN alterations, and TP53 mutations represent common tumor suppressor disruptions across subtypes. [3][7]
Multi-omics analyses have identified three molecular subtypes (CS1, CS2, CS3) with distinct immune landscapes: CS2 tumors are "immunologically hot" with high TMB, neoantigen load, and IFN-γ signaling, while CS1 and CS3 are "immunologically cold" with chromosomal instability and immune evasion mechanisms. [8]
Relationship to Cell of Origin
Melanoma can arise from either melanocyte stem cells or differentiated melanocytes, depending on the anatomical site and oncogenic context. [9-10] The diversity of melanocyte populations across different anatomical locations—including interfollicular epidermis, hair follicles, and mucosal surfaces—contributes to subtype heterogeneity. [9]
Cutaneous melanomas arising in sun-exposed areas likely originate from differentiated epidermal melanocytes that have accumulated UV-induced mutations, explaining their high mutational burden and UV signature. [2] In contrast, acral and mucosal melanomas may arise from melanocyte stem cells or precursors in specialized niches, accounting for their structural alteration-dominated genomes and lack of UV signatures. [2][10]
The transcriptional plasticity observed in melanoma—including phenotype switching between proliferative (MITF-high) and invasive (AXL-high) states—recapitulates distinct melanocyte developmental states from neural crest origins. [5][9] This plasticity enables adaptation to therapeutic pressure and contributes to treatment resistance. [10-11]

column10:
Melanoma subtypes exhibit distinct molecular patterns linked to their cell of origin. Cutaneous melanomas on intermittently sun-exposed skin (e.g. superficial spreading and nodular melanoma) typically show high burdens of UV-signature mutations and common driver mutations in the MAPK pathway, especially BRAFV600E (in ~40–50% of cases) or NRAS mutations【1】. In chronically sun-exposed skin (lentigo maligna melanoma and desmoplastic melanoma), tumors often harbor NRAS or loss-of-function NF1 mutations and an even higher load of UV-linked mutations【1】【2】. By contrast, acral (palms/soles/nailbed) and mucosal (e.g. oral, nasal, genital) melanomas lack UV-signature DNA damage and have lower overall mutation rates【2】. Instead, they frequently exhibit structural genomic alterations – for example, recurrent focal amplifications of oncogenes (CCND1 on 11q, CDK4 on 12q, TERT on 5p, KIT on 4q) are common, and activating mutations or copy gains in KIT occur in roughly 30–40% of acral and mucosal cases【1】【3】. BRAFV600 mutations are comparatively infrequent in acral/mucosal melanoma, seen in a minority of cases, while NRAS or NF1 mutations occur in a subset【1】【2】. Uveal melanomas (arising from melanocytes in the eye) are genetically distinct: they almost uniformly lack UV-signature mutations and BRAF/NRAS mutations, instead driven by Gα-protein mutations in GNAQ or GNA11, often with secondary inactivation of BAP1 or mutations in SF3B1 or EIF1AX, defining molecular subclasses of uveal melanoma【2】. TERT promoter mutations, ubiquitous in cutaneous melanoma, are less common in acral (≈30%) and rare in mucosal melanoma, but gene amplification of TERT can substitute in these subtypes【1】.

Epigenetically, most cutaneous, acral, and mucosal melanomas share a similar global DNA methylation profile, whereas uveal melanomas segregate by a markedly different methylation pattern, reflecting their separate lineage【3】. Still, there are location-specific epigenetic differences: for instance, melanomas of the nasal mucosa frequently show PTEN promoter hypermethylation with loss of PTEN expression, a change seldom seen in other sites【3】. In contrast, mucosal melanomas overall tend to have lower frequencies of CDKN2A or RARB promoter methylation compared to cutaneous tumors【3】. Moreover, the loss of BAP1 in uveal melanoma leads to widespread epigenetic dysregulation (through altered histone ubiquitination), which correlates with an aggressive de-differentiated phenotype.

Distinct transcriptional programs accompany these genetic/epigenetic features. Cutaneous melanomas with BRAFV600 mutations often express a “MITF-high” melanocytic differentiation program (driven by the lineage transcription factor MITF), whereas melanomas from sun-damaged or non-cutaneous sites may shift toward alternate programs. For example, acral and mucosal melanomas show gene expression signatures reflecting less dependence on UV-induced stress responses and often lower immune cell infiltration than high-mutation cutaneous tumors【1】【2】. Desmoplastic melanomas, which arise on chronically sun-exposed skin, uniquely express gene programs associated with Schwann cell and fibroblastic differentiation (e.g. high NGFR/p75^NTR expression) and an inflammatory stroma, consistent with their neurotropic behavior and strong T-cell infiltration【1】【2】. Uveal melanoma cells, in turn, display a transcriptional profile reminiscent of embryonic neural crest/eye development; class II uveal melanomas (with BAP1 loss) show reduced melanocytic differentiation and an increase in stem-cell and neural crest markers, whereas class I tumors (SF3B1 or EIF1AX mutant) retain a more differentiated melanocyte gene signature.

These molecular characteristics are intimately related to each subtype’s cell-of-origin and developmental context. All melanomas derive from neural crest–origin melanocytes, but melanocytes at different anatomical sites or differentiation stages have distinct biology that influences tumor evolution【4】【5】. UV-associated cutaneous melanomas often arise from epidermal melanocytes (sometimes from pre-existing nevi) in intermittently exposed skin【4】. In contrast, lentigo maligna and desmoplastic melanomas on chronically sun-exposed skin may originate from melanocyte stem cells residing in hair follicles or from Schwann cell precursor–like melanocytes in the dermis – consistent with their frequent NF1 mutations and schwannian transcriptomic features【5】. Acral and mucosal melanomas are thought to arise from melanocytes that migrated along embryonic nerve routes to acral skin and mucosal epithelium. Indeed, melanocytes in acral sites have a distinct HOX gene expression profile reflecting limb positional identity, and they may be more prone to chromosomal instability under oncogenic stress than UV-protected epidermal melanocytes【4】. This helps explain why acral/mucosal melanomas favor copy-number driven oncogenesis and often present de novo (rather than from benign nevi). Finally, uveal melanoma’s unique program corresponds to its origin from ocular melanocytes in an immune-privileged environment: the specific GNAQ/GNA11 driver mutations and BAP1-associated epigenetic program mirror the developmental signaling pathways of the eye’s melanocyte lineage【2】【3】. In sum, each melanoma subtype’s characteristic genetic and epigenetic landscape – from mutation spectra to methylation and gene expression profiles – can be understood as a consequence of the cell-of-origin’s developmental state and environment in that anatomic context, which confer differential susceptibility to particular oncogenic alterations【4】【5】.

Melanomas are not a single homogeneous entity but comprise multiple histological subtypes with distinct molecular features, rooted in their cells of origin. Traditional subtyping (superficial spreading, nodular, lentiginous, acral, mucosal, uveal, etc.) correlates with specific genetic mutations. For example, intermittent sun-exposed cutaneous melanomas (like superficial spreading melanoma) commonly carry activating BRAF^V600E mutations – this is the most frequent driver in younger patients/tumors arising from intermittently UV-exposed skin【1】. Such tumors also show moderate mutation burden often with a UV-signature (C>T transitions from UV damage)【2】. In older patients with chronically sun-exposed skin (e.g. facial lentigo maligna melanoma), there is a preponderance of NRAS mutations or inactivation of the tumor suppressor NF1, accompanied by very high total mutation counts with a UV signature【1】. Desmoplastic melanoma, a variant often arising from lentigo maligna, exemplifies this high UV damage: it was found to have some of the highest mutation burdens and frequent NF1 alterations【1】. These patterns underline how UV etiology drives specific genetic changes: high cumulative UV exposure tends to produce NRAS or NF1-driven tumors with many mutations, whereas lower, intermittent UV exposure more often yields BRAF-driven tumors【1】【2】. In all cutaneous cases, the TERT promoter is a common mutational target (mutated in ~50% of cases) to maintain telomeres【1】.

By contrast, acral and mucosal melanomas arise in sun-shielded locations (acral skin of palms/soles/nails; mucous membranes) and accordingly lack UV-signature mutations【2】. Genome-wide analyses show these subtypes have significantly lower point mutation burdens than cutaneous tumors【2】. Instead, they are characterized by frequent copy number variations and structural rearrangements【1】【2】. Hayward et al. (2017) demonstrated that acral and mucosal melanomas accumulate “large-scale genetic aberrations” – e.g. amplifications of chromosomal regions harboring oncogenes and deletions of tumor suppressors – rather than the small UV-induced nucleotide changes prevalent in cutaneous melanoma【2】. Consistent with this, key drivers in acral/mucosal melanoma often involve gene amplifications or mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase/RAS pathway genes. For instance, KIT is often activated: about one-third of acral and mucosal melanomas have either KIT mutations or copy-number gains, whereas KIT alterations are rare in ordinary cutaneous melanoma【1】. Amplification of the CCND1 locus (11q13) and CDK4 (12q14) – driving cell cycle progression – is also enriched in acral melanoma【1】. Notably, the TERT promoter is mutated in a much smaller fraction of mucosal melanomas (~8%) compared to cutaneous cases, although many mucosal tumors instead show TERT gene amplification (5p copy gain) as an alternate mechanism for telomere maintenance【1】【3】. Acral melanomas too have intermediate TERT promoter mutation rates (~30%) and sometimes amplifications【1】. This highlights that while the biological pathways (MAPK activation, cell cycle activation, telomere maintenance) are important across melanoma subtypes, the genetic mechanism by which those pathways are dysregulated can differ by subtype and anatomic origin【1】【2】.

Uveal melanoma, arising from melanocytes in the eye’s uveal tract, is the clearest outlier in terms of genetics. Uveal tumors almost never have BRAF or NRAS mutations – instead, >80% harbor activating mutations in GNAQ or GNA11, genes encoding G-protein alpha subunits in melanocyte signaling【2】. These occur early and are considered initiating oncogenic events in uveal melanoma. Subsequent mutations in BAP1 (a chromatin regulator), SF3B1 (a spliceosome factor), or EIF1AX define molecular subtypes of uveal melanoma with different prognoses【2】. Loss-of-function of BAP1 in uveal melanoma is strongly associated with metastasis, and it correlates with a distinct genome-wide DNA methylation pattern and gene expression profile (called “Class 2” uveal melanoma)【2】【3】. In fact, Jurmeister et al. (2022) showed that unsupervised DNA methylation profiling cleanly separates uveal melanomas from all other melanoma types【3】. In their analysis, cutaneous, acral, mucosal, and even conjunctival melanomas grouped together by methylation marks, whereas uveal melanomas formed a separate cluster, underscoring a fundamentally different epigenetic program【3】. Interestingly, conjunctival melanoma (arising from ocular surface melanocytes exposed to UV) is more similar to cutaneous/mucosal melanoma in mutation profile (it can have BRAF or NRAS mutations) and methylation, whereas the intraocular uveal melanoma remains distinct【3】. This reinforces that tissue of origin drives molecular distinctions: only the melanocytes of the uveal inner eye (which arise from a specific neural crest sub-lineage and dwell in a low-UV, immune-privileged site) give rise to the GNAQ-mutant/BAP1-mutant uveal melanoma subtype【2】.

Beyond mutations, epigenetic landscapes vary by subtype in ways connected to developmental origin and environment. As mentioned, uveal melanomas have a unique DNA methylation and chromatin state. But among cutaneous, acral, and mucosal melanomas, there is a surprising overall similarity in global methylation patterns【3】. Jurmeister et al. found that primary-site identification via methylome is challenging for non-uveal melanomas because, at a whole-genome level, their methylation profiles were largely overlapping【3】. Nonetheless, certain promoter-specific methylation events differ by subtype: for example, mucosal melanomas showed significantly lower frequencies of CDKN2A promoter methylation than cutaneous melanomas【3】. Also, all tested paranasal sinus melanomas in that study had PTEN promoter methylation and loss of PTEN protein, a feature much less common in other mucosal or cutaneous sites【3】. These epigenetic modifications can cooperate with genomic mutations (e.g. silencing additional tumor suppressors like PTEN) and often reflect adaptation to the local tissue context (e.g. sinonasal mucosa). Likewise, gene expression (“transcriptional”) programs in melanoma align with both the driver mutations and the melanoma’s lineage. Cutaneous melanomas often display a MITF-driven melanocytic program, since MITF is a crucial lineage transcription factor often upregulated by BRAFV600E signaling. In contrast, melanomas with alternative drivers or arising from less pigmented cell types can show non-melanocytic gene signatures. A salient example is desmoplastic melanoma, which frequently loses classical melanocytic markers and instead expresses genes associated with Schwann cells, nerve growth factor receptors, and extracellular matrix remodeling【1】【2】. This is consistent with its histology (fibrosis, neurotropism) and excellent response to immune checkpoint therapy (due in part to a high mutational load and an “inflamed” gene expression microenvironment with many immune genes). Another example is the distinction between “high-MITF” versus “AXL-high” melanoma cell states: while both can occur within a tumor (reflecting phenotype switching), certain subtypes might predispose to one state. For instance, acral/mucosal melanomas, which often have lower MITF levels and higher frequency of copy number alterations, may more readily adopt an AXL-high, invasive, and drug-resistant transcriptional state (though research is ongoing)【2】. Moreover, site-related expression patterns have been noted: acral melanomas show enrichment of genes related to keratinocyte signaling and wound healing (perhaps due to pressure or injury at acral sites), whereas mucosal melanomas express gene sets related to mucosal biology (e.g. pigmentation genes plus mucin/stromal interaction genes) – data that are beginning to emerge from transcriptomic comparisons.

Crucially, these genetic, epigenetic, and expression differences are thought to arise because melanocyte populations differ by anatomic site and differentiation stage. Melanocytes originate from neural crest cells, but their developmental journey varies. It’s been shown in animal models that melanomas can originate from either fully differentiated melanocytes or from less differentiated melanocyte stem/progenitor cells, depending on the context【5】. Castro-Pérez et al. (2023) review highlights that mouse models can initiate melanoma from melanocyte stem cells (e.g. in hair follicles) or from mature melanocytes, with different outcomes【5】. This suggests human melanoma subtypes might trace back to distinct cells of origin: for example, a superficial spreading melanoma might develop from an existing nevus (clonal expansion of differentiated melanocytes in the epidermis), whereas a lentiginous melanoma on heavily sun-damaged skin might arise from a dormant melanocyte stem cell that was activated by chronic UV-induced injury and accumulated mutations【5】. Such a stem cell origin could explain the often multi-focal, field-like growth of lentigo maligna. In acral skin and mucosal membranes, melanocytes are relatively sparse and are thought to originate from Schwann cell precursors associated with peripheral nerves (since during embryogenesis, some neural crest cells colonize distal sites via nerve migration)【4】【5】. Consistent with this, Weiss et al. (2022) demonstrated that melanocytes from different body sites carry positional molecular identities (e.g. HOX gene expression patterns) and that these identities influence which oncogenes can transform them【4】. Their work showed that certain oncogenic mutations are preferentially successful in certain anatomic contexts – pointing to differences in the “oncogenic competence” of melanocytes depending on their developmental history【4】. For instance, acral melanocytes (HOX13-positive, limb-type) might require a different set of mutations (or incur chromosomal instability) to become malignant, whereas truncal melanocytes (HOX10/HOXB-positive) readily transform with BRAFV600E plus TERT promoter mutation【4】. This aligns with the observed reality: BRAFV600E-mutant melanomas are common on the trunk but relatively rare in acral areas, whereas acral melanomas more often show KIT or focal amplifications. Mucosal melanocytes, too, reside in unique niches (such as sinonasal or genitourinary mucosa) often near nerve fibers, and may have a lower baseline mutation rate but greater propensity for structural variations, reflecting differences in how these cells handle DNA damage or replication stress. Finally, the uveal melanocyte lineage in the eye arises from a specific subset of neural crest cells and develops in an environment with distinct growth factors and immune privilege; accordingly, transformation of these cells follows a unique route (GNAQ/GNA11 activation and BAP1 loss) that diverges from cutaneous melanoma【2】. The strong link between BAP1 loss, chromatin state, and an undifferentiated phenotype in uveal melanoma underscores how the cell of origin’s epigenetic program dictates tumor behavior: loss of BAP1 in uveal melanocytes likely pushes them back toward a primitive, migratory neural crest-like state, which is associated with high metastatic risk.

In summary, each melanoma histological subtype can be defined by a characteristic combination of mutations (genetic features), methylation/chromatin patterns (epigenetic features), and gene expression programs (transcriptional features). These differences are not random; rather, they reflect the melanocyte of origin’s developmental pathway and the environmental exposures at the tumor’s site of origin. Modern genomic studies and comparative analyses have cemented the concept that melanoma is a collection of related but distinct diseases arising from the diverse lineage of melanocytes scattered throughout the body【4】【5】. Recognizing these distinctions is important not only for understanding melanoma biology but also for developing subtype-specific prevention and treatment strategies (for instance, c-KIT inhibitors in KIT-mutant acral/mucosal melanoma, or tailored immune approaches for uveal melanoma’s unique microenvironment). The evidence thus supports that the genetic/epigenetic hallmarks of each melanoma subtype are a direct consequence of where and how that melanoma began – linking back to the cell (and context) of origin in each case【5】.
column11:
Rabbie, R., Ferguson, P., Molina‐Aguilar, C., Adams, D. J., & Robles‐Espinoza, C. D. (2019). Melanoma subtypes: genomic profiles, prognostic molecular markers and therapeutic possibilities. The Journal of Pathology, 247(5), 539–551.

Hayward, N. K., Wilmott, J. S., Waddell, N., Johansson, P. A., Field, M. A., Nones, K., … & Scolyer, R. A. (2017). Whole-genome landscapes of major melanoma subtypes. Nature, 545(7653), 175–180.

Jurmeister, P., Wrede, N., Hoffmann, I., Vollbrecht, C., Heim, D., Schmitt, W. D., … & Capper, D. (2022). Mucosal melanomas of different anatomic sites share a common global DNA methylation profile with cutaneous melanoma but show location-dependent patterns of genetic and epigenetic alterations. The Journal of Pathology, 256(1), 61–70.

Weiss, J. M., Hunter, M. V., Cruz, N. M., Baggiolini, A., Tagore, M., Ma, Y., … & Khavari, P. A. (2022). Anatomic position determines oncogenic specificity in melanoma. Nature, 604(7905), 354–361.

Castro-Pérez, E., Singh, M., Sadangi, S., Mela-Sánchez, C., & Setaluri, V. (2023). Connecting the dots: Melanoma cell of origin, tumor cell plasticity, trans-differentiation, and drug resistance. Pigment Cell & Melanoma Research, 36(5), 330–347.
column12:
Melanoma is a heterogeneous disease classified into distinct histological subtypes, each possessing specific genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptional features that are associated with their unique microenvironments and developmental origins from neural crest cells [1]. These differences impact clinical behavior and therapeutic response [1]. 

Melanoma subtypes exhibit diverse molecular profiles, suggesting that the cell of origin, likely a melanocyte precursor cell, is influenced by both intrinsic genetic events and extrinsic factors from its specific anatomical location [1]. 
Genetic Features
Different melanoma subtypes are characterized by mutually exclusive genetic alterations [1]. 
Cutaneous Melanoma (CM) This subtype has the highest tumor mutation burden and often features mutations in BRAF, NRAS, or NF1 genes, which activate the MAPK signaling pathway [1]. The origin is generally considered to be from melanocytes in the skin, where UV radiation is a primary mutagenic factor contributing to its high mutational load [1].
Acral Melanoma (AM) and Mucosal Melanoma (MM) These subtypes, arising in less sun-exposed areas, display lower mutation burdens and are less frequently associated with BRAF, NRAS, or NF1 mutations [1]. Instead, they are more often characterized by KIT gene amplifications or mutations, as well as mutations in GNAQ/GNA11 genes [1]. Their origins are linked to melanocytes in specific mucosal or acral sites, and their unique genetic landscape reflects different environmental and developmental influences compared to CM [1].
Uveal Melanoma (UM) Arising in the eye, UM is genetically distinct from other forms of melanoma. It is largely characterized by mutations in GNAQ or GNA11 genes, which activate the phospholipase C pathway [1]. UM has a very low mutation burden [1]. The developmental origin of the uveal melanocyte is a crucial factor in its distinct biology [1]. 
Epigenetic Features
The epigenetic landscape is also diverse across subtypes [1]. The unique developmental trajectory and microenvironment of each melanocyte origin point to distinct epigenetic programming that is maintained in the cancer cells [1]. For instance, differential DNA methylation patterns have been observed that correlate with the primary site of the tumor [1]. These epigenetic modifications are thought to help shape the subtype-specific transcriptional programs [1]. 
Transcriptional Programs and Cell of Origin
Transcriptional profiling reveals subtype-specific gene expression patterns [1]. These programs often reflect the developmental stage and lineage of the cell of origin. 
The expression of microphthalmia-associated transcription factor (MITF) is critical in melanoma [1]. Subtypes can exhibit different levels and activity of MITF. A "melanocytic" phenotype is generally associated with higher MITF expression, while a "neural crest stem cell" or "mesenchymal" phenotype is associated with lower MITF expression and the expression of markers like Axl [1].
The specific microenvironments (skin, mucosa, eye) encountered during neural crest cell migration and differentiation are believed to impose unique transcriptional and epigenetic constraints, ultimately contributing to the distinct molecular subtypes of melanoma observed in different anatomical locations [1].
column13: [1] Oh, S., G Sellers, L. A., & Feuerstein, M. A. (2018). Melanoma subtypes: developmental origin and clinical implications. Cells, 7(12), 220.

column3: How are developmental programs of neural crest and melanocytes co-opted by melanoma for adaptation to the environments and therapeutic resistance?
column6:
ANSWER: Melanoma co-opts developmental programs of its progenitor cells, the neural crest and melanocytes, to adapt to changing environments and develop therapeutic resistance through several key mechanisms. It reactivates a plastic, migratory, and stem-like state resembling that of neural crest stem cells (NCSCs), which is intrinsically resistant to therapy. This is driven by the dysregulation of core developmental transcription factors such as SOX10, MSX1, YY1, and PAX3. This dedifferentiation is a central component of "phenotype switching," where melanoma cells dynamically transition between a proliferative, melanocytic state (often MITF-high) and an invasive, NCSC-like state (often MITF-low, AXL-high). This heterogeneity allows subpopulations to survive therapeutic pressures and environmental stresses like hypoxia or nutrient deprivation. Melanoma also hijacks specific developmental signaling pathways, such as the LPAR1-RAPGEF5-RAP1A axis, which is normally active in neuronal progenitors but not mature melanocytes, to drive proliferation, invasion, and resistance to MAPK inhibitors by activating mTOR and YAP signaling. Furthermore, melanoma repurposes developmental metabolic programs, demonstrating vulnerabilities to nucleotide depletion similar to neural crest cells and a dependence on lipid metabolism and peroxisomes for survival, especially in drug-tolerant persister cells. Finally, it co-opts physical and mechanical properties, such as upregulating the nuclear envelope protein LAP1C, to increase nuclear deformability, a trait essential for the extensive migration seen in both neural crest development and cancer metastasis. These co-opted programs collectively endow melanoma with the plasticity and adaptability needed for progression, metastasis, and the development of intrinsic and acquired drug resistance.

ANALYSIS:
### **1. Introduction: Melanoma and Its Developmental Origins**

Melanoma is a type of cancer that originates from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing the pigment melanin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanoma). While most commonly found in the skin, melanomas can also arise in other tissues containing melanocytes, such as the mouth, eyes, or intestines. In rare instances, it can even occur as a primary tumor in the lungs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melanoma). Melanocytes themselves are derived from a transient embryonic cell population known as the neural crest. This developmental lineage is critical, as melanoma cells often share characteristics with melanocyte precursors and neural crest cells, suggesting that they reactivate or "co-opt" the developmental programs of their cellular ancestors to drive tumor progression, metastasis, and therapeutic resistance (PMID:25109840; PMID:19795394).

### **2. Developmental Programs of Neural Crest Cells and Melanocytes**

#### **2.1. The Neural Crest Developmental Program**

The neural crest is a temporary structure that forms during vertebrate embryonic development at the border between the neural plate and the epidermal ectoderm. Through a process called epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), neural crest cells (NCCs) delaminate from this structure and migrate extensively throughout the embryo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_crest). NCCs are multipotent progenitors that give rise to a vast and diverse array of cell types, including melanocytes, peripheral neurons and glia, craniofacial cartilage and bone, and smooth muscle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_crest).

The developmental potential of NCCs is exceptionally broad, challenging the paradigm of progressive lineage restriction after gastrulation. For instance, cranial neural crest cells (CNCCs), which originate from the ectoderm, can generate both ectodermal derivatives like neurons and mesenchymal tissues like bone and cartilage (PMID:33542111; PMID:36724256). This broad potential is governed by a complex gene regulatory network (GRN) that integrates intrinsic and environmental signals to control cell identity (PMID:31702881). Key transcription factors, such as TFAP2A, are crucial for specifying neural crest fate (PMID:28886367). Studies show that NCCs exist in a transient state of heightened chromatin accessibility, with biases toward either neuronal or ectomesenchymal fates, indicating a highly dynamic and plastic cellular state during development (PMID:36724256; PMID:31171666).

#### **2.2. The Melanocyte Developmental Program**

Melanocytes are the pigment-producing cells that arise from NCCs during embryonic development. This process involves the specification of melanocyte fate in the neural crest, followed by the migration of precursor cells (melanoblasts) to their final destinations in the skin and hair follicles, and their subsequent differentiation (PMID:19795394). In hair follicles, a population of melanocyte stem cells (McSCs) located in the bulge and hair germ area is responsible for regenerating the differentiated, pigment-producing melanocytes that color the hair during its growth phase (PMID:37076619). The proper development and migration of melanocytes are critical, and disruptions in these processes can lead to pigmentation disorders like piebaldism, which is characterized by the congenital absence of melanocytes in specific areas of the skin and hair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piebaldism).

The transcriptional programs governing human melanocyte differentiation are distinct from those in other model organisms, and these human-specific signatures can be used to define patterns of dedifferentiation that are predictive of melanoma prognosis and therapeutic response (PMID:34475532). Many of the genes and pathways essential for normal melanocyte development, specification, and maintenance have been implicated in the formation and progression of melanoma, highlighting the close connection between the normal developmental process and its malignant counterpart (PMID:25109840; PMID:19795394).

### **3. The Concept of Co-option in Cancer Biology**

Co-option, also known as exaptation in evolutionary biology, is a process where a trait that evolved for one function is repurposed for a different function (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exaptation). In cancer biology, this concept describes how tumor cells hijack and repurpose pre-existing biological programs, cellular machinery, and host systems to support their own survival, growth, and dissemination. Cancer cells do not operate in isolation; they actively co-opt components of their local and systemic microenvironments (PMID:27829148; PMID:33442008).

This co-option can occur at multiple levels:
*   **Co-option of Developmental Programs:** Cancer cells can reactivate latent developmental pathways from their cell of origin. These states are often constrained by the organism's "developmental map," meaning cancer cell states are typically proximate to the developmental hierarchy of the original cell type (PMID:38848676).
*   **Co-option of Cellular Machinery:** Tumors can exploit fundamental cellular processes like nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) to downregulate tumor suppressors (PMID:32213869) or alter mitochondrial functions to adapt to the harsh tumor microenvironment and resist chemotherapy (PMID:30820778).
*   **Co-option of Systemic Pathways:** Cancer cells can co-opt systemic signaling pathways, such as the insulin-PI3K cascade, which normally integrates nutrient status with cell growth and survival, to fuel their own proliferation (PMID:32127696).
*   **Co-option of Host Cell Types:** Tumors can recruit and reprogram host cells, such as neutrophils or macrophages, to contribute to disease progression and immune evasion (PMID:30816340; PMID:29130936).
*   **Co-option of Genetic Elements:** Oncogenesis can involve the co-option of transposable elements (TEs) from pluripotent stem cells as regulatory elements to drive aberrant gene expression (PMID:37694973) or the co-option of LTRs from TEs as alternative promoters to activate oncogenes following disruptions in chromatin topology (PMID:40588507).

### **4. Melanoma's Co-option of Neural Crest and Melanocyte Programs**

Melanoma provides a classic example of a cancer that hijacks developmental programs for its own benefit. Its initiation and progression are associated with the transcriptional reprogramming of melanocytes to a state that resembles their neural crest origin (PMID:34281491). This reversion allows melanoma cells to acquire traits like plasticity, invasiveness, and therapeutic resistance, which are characteristic of embryonic neural crest cells.

#### **4.1. Reactivation of a Neural Crest Stem Cell (NCSC)-like State**

A central theme in melanoma adaptation is the dedifferentiation of tumor cells into a neural crest stem cell (NCSC)-like state. This state is molecularly and biologically akin to embryonic neural crest progenitors, exhibiting high invasiveness, plasticity, and self-renewal capacity (PMID:34462276).
*   **Melanoma Initiation:** Live imaging in zebrafish models has shown that melanoma can be initiated when a single melanocyte within a cancer-prone field (carrying BRAF(V600E) and p53 mutations) reactivates an NCP (neural crest progenitor) state, marked by the re-expression of the embryonic gene *crestin* (PMID:26823433). This highlights the re-emergence of an embryonic state as a key event in melanoma initiation.
*   **Therapy Resistance:** Single-cell RNA sequencing of melanoma patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) treated with RAF/MEK inhibitors identified distinct drug-tolerant transcriptional states within the minimal residual disease (MRD). One of these states exhibited a neural crest stem cell (NCSC) program, driven in part by the nuclear receptor RXRG. Antagonizing RXR could mitigate the accumulation of these NCSC-like cells and delay the development of resistance, identifying this developmental state as a key driver of relapse (PMID:30017245).
*   **Shared Molecular Machinery:** Aggressive tumor cells, including melanoma, share many characteristics and molecular markers with multipotent, invasive embryonic progenitors like the neural crest (PMID:18629870). Studies have shown that malignant melanoma cells hijack parts of the neural crest developmental program, including the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT)-like events used by NCCs for migration, to facilitate metastasis (PMID:23774755).

#### **4.2. Hijacking Specific Developmental Pathways for Survival and Resistance**

Melanoma co-opts specific signaling and metabolic pathways that are active during neural crest and melanocyte development to sustain its growth and survive therapy.

*   **The LPAR1-Axis:** A transcriptome juxtaposition study comparing human NCLSCs, melanocytes, and melanoma cultures identified lysophosphatidic acid receptor 1 (LPAR1) as a gene highly expressed in NCLSCs and melanoma cells but not in mature melanocytes. LPAR1 is a G12/13-coupled receptor known to drive the proliferation of neuronal progenitor cells. In melanoma, the LPAR1 signaling axis (LPAR1→RAPGEF5→RAP1A) promotes proliferation, mobility, invasiveness, and both intrinsic and acquired resistance to BRAF/MEK inhibitors by sustaining mTOR and YAP activity. LPAR1 expression increases as melanoma progresses and upon acquisition of drug resistance, making it a novel therapeutic target for eliminating the therapy-resistant, dedifferentiated NCLSC-like melanoma cell population (PMID:34462276).
*   **Metabolic Reprogramming:** Melanoma cells co-opt developmental metabolic dependencies.
    *   **Nucleotide Metabolism:** Neural crest cells have a unique sensitivity to nucleotide depletion. This developmental susceptibility is conserved in melanoma. Inhibitors of the enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH), which is involved in pyrimidine biosynthesis, abrogate neural crest development and also decrease melanoma growth, highlighting a shared metabolic vulnerability that can be therapeutically exploited (PMID:21430780; PMID:34281491).
    *   **Lipid Metabolism:** A zebrafish melanoma model identified a transcriptional program linking a pigmented, melanocytic cell state to a dependence on lipid droplets and fatty acid oxidative metabolism. This metabolic state is conserved in human melanomas and is associated with poor patient outcomes, representing a metabolic vulnerability linked to a specific differentiation state (PMID:37268606). Furthermore, melanoma cells tolerate MAPK inhibitors by reprogramming lipid metabolism via peroxisomes. A specific drug-tolerant subpopulation of "starved-like melanoma cells" (SMCs), marked by CD36 expression, is dependent on peroxisome and UGCG-mediated ceramide metabolism for survival. Co-targeting peroxisome biogenesis (via PEX3) and ceramide metabolism (via UGCG) can eliminate these persister cells and delay resistance (PMID:37616051).
    *   **YY1-Controlled Metabolism:** The transcription factor Yin Yang 1 (YY1) is a critical regulator of NCSC development, governing proliferation and survival. In a melanoma mouse model, reducing YY1 levels prevented tumorigenesis. Mechanistically, YY1 controls multiple metabolic pathways and protein synthesis in both NCSCs and melanoma, acting as part of a gene regulatory network that includes MITF and c-MYC. This demonstrates that both normal NCSC development and melanoma formation depend on an intricate, YY1-controlled metabolic program (PMID:30951662).

*   **Phenotype Switching and Environmental Adaptation:** Melanoma's ability to co-opt developmental programs confers remarkable plasticity, allowing it to adapt to diverse microenvironmental cues.
    *   **The Aged Microenvironment:** The aged microenvironment can drive melanoma progression and therapy resistance. Aged dermal fibroblasts secrete the Wnt antagonist sFRP2, which suppresses β-catenin and MITF in melanoma cells. This leads to the loss of the redox effector APE1, rendering the melanoma cells more resistant to targeted therapy (vemurafenib) and promoting angiogenesis and metastasis (PMID:27042933).
    *   **Hypoxia:** A hypoxic microenvironment can trigger a switch in melanoma cells from a proliferative, ROR1-positive phenotype to an invasive, ROR2-positive phenotype by activating noncanonical Wnt5A signaling. This switch also induces a tenfold decrease in sensitivity to BRAF inhibitors, directly linking an environmental stressor to the co-option of a developmental signaling pathway for therapy resistance (PMID:24104062).
    *   **Brain Metastasis:** To survive and grow in the brain, melanoma cells co-opt mechanisms related to neurodegenerative pathologies. They secrete amyloid beta (Aβ), which activates surrounding astrocytes to a pro-metastatic state and prevents microglia from phagocytosing the tumor cells. This demonstrates a novel co-option of neuro-inflammatory pathways for adaptation to a specific metastatic niche (PMID:35262173).

#### **4.3. Co-option of Molecular and Physical Mechanisms**

The reactivation of developmental programs involves the dysregulation of key molecular players and the repurposing of physical cellular properties.

*   **Core Developmental Transcription Factors:** Several transcription factors that orchestrate neural crest and melanocyte development are central to melanoma plasticity.
    *   **SOX10:** Crucial for NC cell survival and melanocyte specification, SOX10 is also a key part of the melanoma-initiating transcriptional program. ATAC-Seq analysis of zebrafish melanomas identified melanoma-specific enhancers for the *sox10* gene, demonstrating how cancer cells can co-opt developmental regulatory elements to drive oncogene expression (PMID:34099848).
    *   **MSX1:** An early NC specifier, MSX1 expression is reactivated in melanoma and can reprogram differentiated melanocytes and melanoma cells to a dedifferentiated, NCSC-like state, promoting an invasive phenotype associated with poor prognosis (PMID:34071193).
    *   **MITF:** The "master regulator" of melanogenesis, MITF levels act as a rheostat controlling melanoma cell state. Intermediate MITF levels are associated with proliferation, while low levels are linked to an invasive, drug-resistant phenotype, and high levels are linked to a differentiated, G1-arrested state. This dynamic regulation of MITF is a key driver of phenotype switching (PMID:34071193).
    *   **PAX3, FOXD3:** These TFs, which regulate MITF expression during development, are also involved in controlling melanoma cell state and drug resistance. For example, FOXD3 mediates resistance to BRAF/MEK inhibitors by upregulating ERBB3 (PMID:34071193).

*   **Mechanical Plasticity for Invasion:** Metastasis requires cancer cells to navigate through tight physical spaces. Neural crest cells are masters of migration through constrictive embryonic environments. Metastatic melanoma cells co-opt mechanisms to enhance their physical deformability. They exhibit increased expression of the inner nuclear membrane protein LAP1, specifically the shorter isoform LAP1C. LAP1C expression supports nuclear envelope blebbing and allows for a weaker coupling between the nuclear envelope and lamina. This renders the nucleus more adaptable and deformable, facilitating constrained migration and invasion, thereby contributing to melanoma's aggressiveness (PMID:36624187).

### **5. Conclusion: A Disease of Developmental Regression**

Melanoma's adaptability and resistance are deeply rooted in its ability to co-opt the developmental programs of its neural crest and melanocyte ancestors. This is not simply a random process but a structured regression to more primitive, plastic, and migratory cellular states. By reactivating NCSC-like transcriptional and metabolic networks, melanoma gains access to a repertoire of embryonic behaviors that are highly advantageous for surviving therapeutic attack and colonizing new environments. The hijacking of specific pathways like the LPAR1 axis for drug resistance, the repurposing of lipid metabolism for survival, and the re-engagement of mechanical properties like nuclear plasticity for invasion all underscore a central theme: melanoma's progression is a form of developmental pathology. The insights gained from studying these co-opted developmental programs reveal unique vulnerabilities. Rather than targeting the end-stage consequences of malignancy, therapies aimed at the core developmental dependencies—be they signaling pathways like LPAR1, metabolic programs like ceramide synthesis, or key transcription factors—represent a rational and promising strategy to dismantle the foundations of melanoma's resilience and adaptability.

column8:
Melanoma cells co-opt neural crest developmental programs through reactivation of key transcription factors (SOX10, MITF, PAX3, FOXD3, MSX1) and signaling pathways that govern neural crest specification, migration, and differentiation. This developmental reprogramming enables phenotypic plasticity, allowing melanoma cells to switch between proliferative/differentiated and invasive/stem-like states in response to microenvironmental pressures and therapeutic stress. [1-3] The reemergence of neural crest stem cell (NCSC)-like properties confers survival advantages, including enhanced migration, self-renewal capacity, and resistance to both targeted therapies and immunotherapies. [4-5]

Neural Crest Transcription Factors Drive Melanoma Plasticity
Five master transcription factors central to neural crest development—MSX1, MITF, SOX10, PAX3, and FOXD3—are reactivated in melanoma and orchestrate phenotypic switching. These factors regulate the balance between proliferative and invasive states, with MITF serving as the central rheostat. [1] MSX1 induces neural crest-like reprogramming that promotes melanoma progression by driving a phenotypic switch from an E-cadherin-high nonmigratory state to a ZEB1-high invasive state, with MSX1 depletion significantly inhibiting metastasis in vivo. [6] SOX10 forms complexes with chromatin-modifying enzymes like ATAD2, allowing expression of downstream oncogenic and neural crest programs that determine oncogenic competence. [7]
The transcriptional plasticity observed in melanoma recapitulates distinct melanocyte developmental states from neural crest origins. Melanoma cells can transition between differentiated melanocytic phenotypes (high MITF, melanin production) and dedifferentiated neural crest-like states (high invasiveness, stem cell markers). [2-3] This phenotype switching is not random but follows developmental trajectories, with melanoma evolution mirroring the hierarchic process of neural crest differentiation. [8]
Developmental Migration Programs Enable Invasion and Metastasis
Melanoma cells hijack the embryonic neural crest migration program to facilitate invasion and metastasis. When exposed to embryonic microenvironments, metastatic melanoma cells dynamically regulate genes associated with neural crest induction, delamination, and migration, exploiting neural crest-related receptor tyrosine kinases to increase plasticity. [9-10] The melanocyte differentiation program itself predisposes to metastasis after neoplastic transformation, with the master regulator Slug (SNAI2) being required for metastasis of transformed melanoma cells. [11]
Melanoma cells revive embryonic epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) programs to dissociate from surrounding keratinocytes, similar to how neural crest cells undergo EMT to exit the dorsal neural tube. [10][12] EMT-inducing transcription factors serve as major drivers of phenotype switching between differentiated/proliferative and neural crest stem cell-like/invasive states, contributing to intratumoral heterogeneity. [13]
Neural Crest Stem Cell-Like States Mediate Therapeutic Resistance
The emergence of NCSC-like populations in minimal residual disease (MRD) is a critical determinant of nongenetic resistance to targeted therapies. In melanoma exposed to MAPK pathway inhibitors, a transient neural crest stem cell population emerges through a glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF)-dependent signaling cascade that activates the AKT survival pathway in a focal adhesion kinase (FAK)-dependent manner. [5] Ablation of this NCSC population through FAK inhibition delays relapse, though tumors that ultimately escape exhibit resistance-conferring genetic alterations. [5]
Neural crest-associated genes like LPAR1 and ERRFI1 are upregulated during melanoma progression and acquisition of therapeutic resistance. LPAR1 activity increases following BRAF/MEK inhibitor treatment, and genetic inhibition of LPAR1 potentiates therapy efficacy while ablating melanoma migration and invasion. [14] Similarly, ERRFI1 expression is elevated in metastatic melanoma, negatively correlates with melanocytic differentiation markers, and its downregulation increases susceptibility to BRAF inhibition by diminishing MAPK and AKT pathway activation. [15]
The CD271/p75 neurotrophin receptor, a neural crest marker, plays convergent roles in tumor initiation, phenotype switching, and reprogramming of metastatic melanoma, contributing to melanoma plasticity. [16] Melanoma cells expressing neural crest markers demonstrate multipotent characteristics and can undergo trans-differentiation along vascular and neural lineages, properties associated with stem cell-like behavior and drug resistance. [3]
Developmental Chromatin Programs Determine Oncogenic Competence
The transforming ability of BRAF and other oncogenic mutations depends on the intrinsic transcriptional program present in the cell of origin. Neural crest progenitors and melanoblasts are readily transformed, while differentiated melanocytes are less responsive to mutations. [7] This oncogenic competence is mediated by higher expression of chromatin-modifying enzymes in progenitor populations, such as ATAD2, which forms complexes with SOX10 to enable expression of oncogenic programs. [7]
Melanoma can arise from either melanocyte stem cells or differentiated melanocytes depending on anatomical site and oncogenic context, with different cells of origin potentially explaining the molecular heterogeneity observed across melanoma subtypes. [2-3] The cellular composition of MRD deterministically imposes distinct drug resistance evolutionary paths, with NCSC-enriched MRD favoring nongenetic resistance mechanisms. [5]
Metabolic Vulnerabilities Inherited from Neural Crest
Neural crest cells have unique sensitivity to nucleotide depletion, a metabolic vulnerability conserved in melanoma. The pyrimidine biosynthesis enzyme DHODH is particularly critical for neural crest-derived tissues, and nucleotide stress responses that affect neural crest development can be exploited therapeutically in melanoma. [17] This developmental susceptibility provides a metabolic target that may circumvent resistance mechanisms.
Microenvironmental Reprogramming and Plasticity
The embryonic microenvironment can reprogram metastatic melanoma cells to assume neural crest cell-like phenotypes. When transplanted adjacent to premigratory neural crest cells in chick embryos, human metastatic melanoma cells do not form tumors but instead invade along neural crest migratory pathways, populate peripheral structures, and express both melanocyte-specific (MART-1) and neuronal (Tuj1) markers. [18] This demonstrates the remarkable plasticity of melanoma cells and their ability to respond to developmental cues.
The glia/melanocyte fate decision during neural crest development has implications for melanoma plasticity. Schwann cell precursors serve as a secondary source of melanocytes during development, and during melanomagenesis, cells can exhibit both melanocytic and glial features, suggesting reactivation of this developmental plasticity. [19]
